Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the blooming frequency of the pagoda flower by stating that it only blooms once every 400 years in the Himalayas.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the photograph actually shows a plant called Rheum nobile, not a pagoda flower.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or scientific sources to back up the claim of the pagoda flower blooming once every 400 years.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the photograph depicts a pagoda flower without verifying its accuracy.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores the alternative explanation that the photograph shows a different plant, Rheum nobile, which is native to the Himalayas but does not bloom once every 400 years.
Falters at times: The claim falters by misidentifying the plant in the photograph as a pagoda flower when it is actually Rheum nobile.
Understate: No understatement bias is evident in this claim.
